title: I'll stop banning Zoe when Riot reworks her Mario Kart W to not be wildly unpredictable.
body:
Even with the knowledge that a minion has *a* spell (you don't even know what spell, just that it's a spell), there is a drastic difference between her getting two Smites and a Cleanse and her getting two Gunblades and a Teleport. Her W will be impossible to balance meaningfully in its current iteration - it will be weak in some games and bonkers in others.

Quoting myself because way too many people don't understand what I'm getting at and think this is just a "nerf Zoe" thread.

>
> And that's the issue - it's inherently unbalanceable. My idea for something that would be better is that:
> 
> -Every large minion and large monster would drop a shard
> -Shards would give a variable amount of points - more points later into the game
> -You can "buy" a spell for use using points
> -Buying a certain spell temporarily increases its cost - so you can't just keep spamming cleanse to be gank-proof, for example.
> 
> This way it's more consistent and predictable, and removes the edge cases while making sure that Zoe can at least get *something* out of every drop.

Once again completely missing the point. Regardless of what you do, the game state can be COMPLETELY different based on what she gets. She can get Smite and pretty much get nothing from it, or she can get Teleport and have a free back. How is it competitive for such a wildly different potential result to stem from the same action in the same situation?

How is it not competitive? Reacting to RNG on both sides is skill, and the more skilled player would win, right?

MMOs have had competitive PvP for far longer than League has even been an idea, and they all have oodles of RNG.

You could have a different team win playoffs, not because one team did objectively better than another, but because one team got extremely lucky, or got completely screwed, *in the exact same situation.* Think about it from an analyst perspective. Who wants to go "Zoe going for that spell could have been worth it, but she got Cleanse vs Zed", or "you should just give up the spell here and hope she gets something garbage from it"?

This is one of the many reasons Riot's recent post on RNG bothered me: according to that official post, Zoe's W was acceptable because it could be anticipated, and presumably gave the enemy adequate time and options to prepare for whichever effect she got. It can't, and it doesn't. In lane, the time between a random spell dropping to the ground, Zoe getting it, and Zoe applying it, is often far too small, and even when there is enough time, some effects simply cannot be outplayed (particularly since Riot has claimed in the past that they don't initially balance around summoner spells, namely Flash). Moreover, effects like Redemption or Teleport cannot be properly anticipated unless the literal entire enemy team is constantly observing Zoe at all times to see whichever effects she gets. Perhaps there might be an element of creativity at higher levels of play to the usage of her W, but as a baseline it mostly feels like each minion drop is a roulette roll for either a dud, or an active so good it can secure Zoe her lane and even snowball the game beyond that.

Zoe may not be at a high win rate now, but she is certainly not in a healthy spot either, and I would personally support buffs to her, provided that she were made significantly healthier. Her W may have been an experiment in RNG mechanics, but I think there's an overall consensus that this experiment has already turned out unsuccessful. Making her current W much more predictable for everyone involved could be a first step towards making her healthier, and could allow her to be made more powerful as needed.
At the very least, you think they would let both players see what summoner spell the minion would drop...

And that's the issue - it's inherently unbalanceable. My idea for something that would be better is that:

-Every large minion and large monster would drop a shard
-Shards would give a variable amount of points - more points later into the game
-You can "buy" a spell for use using points
-Buying a certain spell temporarily increases its cost - so you can't just keep spamming cleanse to be gank-proof, for example.

This way it's more consistent and predictable, and removes the edge cases while making sure that Zoe can at least get *something* out of every drop.
What if the spell shard displayed what it contained, and then over popped it took like 5 seconds or so to arm and be useable? That way both players could play around the contents of the orb.
